headline.main: Shorter Hours, but Not for Truckers and Temps

docs.abstract: A look at the decline in weekly hours worked shows a big drop for retail, which may be influenced by the coming health mandate. Trucking and temp help services, however, have increased weekly hours.
docs.snippet: A look at the decline in weekly hours worked shows a big drop for retail, which may be influenced by the coming health mandate. Trucking and temp help services, however, have increased weekly hours.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans are trying to turn President Obama’s health care law into an election weapon and are preparing to exploit every problem and complaint that arises as it is carried out.

headline.seo: Republicans Readying New Offensive Over Health Law
headline.main: As Midterms Loom, Democrats Worry About Health Law
headline.print_headline: New Worries For Democrats On Health Law

docs.abstract: Republicans are trying to turn Pres Obama's health care law into election weapon in 2014 midterms, preparing to exploit every problem and complaint that arises as it is carried out; as administration struggles to put in place the final, complex piece of signature legislation, Democrats are worried that major snags will cause political nightmare.
docs.snippet: Republicans are trying to turn President Obama’s health care law into an election weapon and are preparing to exploit every problem and complaint that arises as it is carried out.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Weeks before a new edition of the so-called bible of mental disorders is released, the federal government’s most prominent psychiatric expert said it had a scientific “lack of validity.”

headline.seo: Psychiatry’s New Guide Falls Short, Experts Say
headline.main: Psychiatry’s Guide Is Out of Touch With Science, Experts Say
headline.print_headline: Psychiatry’s New Guide Falls Short, Experts Say

docs.abstract: Dr Thomas R Insel, director of National Institute of Mental Health, says latest edition of Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, or DSM, suffers from scientific 'lack of validity;' says so-called bible of mental health does not reflect complexity of many disorders, and its way of categorizing mental illness should not guide research.
docs.snippet: Weeks before a new edition of the so-called bible of mental disorders is released, the federal government’s most prominent psychiatric expert said it had a scientific “lack of validity.”

keywords.value: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and BENEDICT CAREY

docs.lead_paragraph: The drug maker is now selling its billion-dollar erectile dysfunction drug, among the world’s most counterfeited, directly to men with a prescription.

headline.main: Facing Black Market, Pfizer Is Looking Online to Sell Viagra
headline.print_headline: Pfizer Turning to Internet to Sell Viagra

docs.abstract: Pfizer is taking unusual step of selling its $2 billion-dollar erectile dysfunction drug Viagra to consumers on its Web site, in effort to establish presence in huge online market for popular blue pill, considered to be among world's most counterfeited drugs; experts estimate that firm could be losing hundreds of millions of dollars annually to black market of online pharmacies.
docs.snippet: The drug maker is now selling its billion-dollar erectile dysfunction drug, among the world’s most counterfeited, directly to men with a prescription.

docs.lead_paragraph: The recession and anemic recovery are behind most of a surprising trend that could help close the federal deficit, new studies show, but higher co-payments have also played a part.

headline.seo: Slowdown in Rise of Health Care Costs May Persist
headline.main: Slowdown in Health Costs’ Rise May Last as Economy Revives
headline.print_headline: Slowdown in Increase of Health Care Costs May Persist, Helping Wages and the Deficit

docs.abstract: Studies by researchers at Harvard University and Henry J Kaiser Family Foundation concur that at least some of bigger-than-expected slowdown in health spending over last few years is unrelated to recession, and might persist as economy recovers; find that rising out-of-pocket costs have played major role decline.
docs.snippet: The recession and anemic recovery are behind most of a surprising trend that could help close the federal deficit, new studies show, but higher co-payments have also played a part.

headline.main: About Half of Adults Lacked Adequate Health Coverage in 2012

docs.abstract: A new Commonwealth Fund report finds that people are increasingly skipping needed health care because they can’t afford it. On the plus side, more young adults are insured.
docs.snippet: A new Commonwealth Fund report finds that people are increasingly skipping needed health care because they can’t afford it. On the plus side, more young adults are insured.

headline.main: Low-Risk Skin Cancers Often Treated Too Aggressively in Elderly, Study Finds

docs.abstract: For the elderly, not only can even supposedly minor procedures have complications, but the cancers grow so slowly that they’re unlikely to cause problems in the patients’ remaining years.
docs.snippet: For the elderly, not only can even supposedly minor procedures have complications, but the cancers grow so slowly that they’re unlikely to cause problems in the patients’ remaining years.
